abstracts.cdata!:
The Liquified Petroleum Gas Transport
            And Distribution Project of Bangladesh Closed on June 30,
            1996, without the project being implemented. Credit
            effectiveness was unsuccessfully extended three times to
            enable the Government to meet the conditions of
            effectiveness. Managerial and technical weaknesses of the
            Borrower emerged as the main reason for the non
            implementation of the project. The key lessons learned from
            the project are the following. (A) One major lesson learned
            from the failure of this project to be implemented is the
            strong inter dependencies among sequential investments. (B)
            Protracted procurement actions under the Second Gas
            Development Project (SGDP) seriously impacted the
            implementation of the Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Project.
            (C) The financial power of the Operating Companies (OCs)
            should be raised adequately so that they have the authority
            to independently process procurement of goods and services
            without going for the approval of Petrobangla or the
            Government of Bangladesh (GOB).
